text:
The Statistics Board
	Establishment 
		There is to be a body corporate to be known as the Statistics Board (inthis Part called “the Board”).
		In Gaelic the Board is to be known as Am Bòrd an Staitistig.
		In Welsh the Board is to be known as Y Bwrdd Ystadegau.
	Status 
		The Board is to exercise its functions on behalf of the Crown.
		Accordingly, the property, rights and liabilities of the Board areproperty, rights and liabilities of the Crown.

Members and staff
	Members 
		The Board is to consist of executive and non-executive members.
		The non-executive members are to be—
			the chairman, appointed by Her Majesty, and
			at least five other persons appointed by the Minister for the CabinetOffice.
		Before appointing any person under subsection (2)(b) the Minister for theCabinet Office must consult the chairman.
		The persons appointed under subsection (2)(b) must include—
			one person who is appointed by the Minister for the Cabinet Office afterconsulting the Scottish Ministers,
			one person who is appointed by the Minister for the Cabinet Office afterconsulting the Welsh Ministers, and
			one person who is appointed by the Minister for the Cabinet Office afterconsulting the Department of Finance and Personnel for Northern Ireland.
		The Minister for the Cabinet Office may, after consulting the chairman,designate one of the non-executive members appointed under subsection (2)(b)as deputy chairman.
		The executive members are to be—
			the National Statistician (see section 5), and
			two other employees of the Board, appointed by the non-executive members.
		A person may not be both a non-executive member of the Board and anemployee of the Board.
	Non-executive members
		A non-executive member of the Board is to be appointed—
			for at least one and no more than five years, and
			on such other terms and conditions as the person making the appointmentthinks fit.
		A non-executive member is to hold and vacate office in accordance with theterms and conditions of his appointment, subject as follows.
		A non-executive member may resign at any time by notice in writing to theMinister for the Cabinet Office.
		The person appointing a non-executive member may dismiss him by notice inwriting on the grounds that—
			the member has been absent from meetings of the Board without permission ofthe Board for a period of more than three months,
			the member is the subject of a bankruptcy restrictions order (or interimorder),
			the member has had his estate sequestrated in Scotland or, under Scots law,has made a composition or arrangement with, or granted a trust deed for, hiscreditors,
			the member is unfit for office by reason of misconduct,
			the member has failed to comply with the terms of his appointment, or
			the member is otherwise unable, unfit or unwilling to perform hisfunctions.
		Where— 
			a non-executive member ceases to be a member otherwise than on the expiryof his term of office, and
			it appears to the Minister for the Cabinet Office that there arecircumstances which make it right for him to receive compensation,
				the Board may pay him compensation of an amount approved by the Minister forthe Cabinet Office.
		A person who has ceased to be a non-executive member is eligible for re-appointment (on any number of occasions).
	Executive members and other staff
		The Board is to have—
			an officer known as the National Statistician, and
			an officer known as the Head of Assessment.
		The National Statistician is to be—
			appointed by Her Majesty, and
			employed by the Board on the terms and conditions of his appointment (whichmay include provision relating to dismissal).
		The Head of Assessment is to be—
			appointed by the non-executive members of the Board, and
			employed by the Board on the terms and conditions of his appointment.
		The Board is to have such other employees as it may appoint.
		The persons appointed under subsection (4) are to be employed on the termsand conditions of their appointment.
		The Board may only appoint persons under subsection (4) with the approvalof the Minister for the Civil Service as to numbers and terms and conditionsof employment.
		Service as an employee of the Board is service in the civil service of theState.
		The employees of the Board who are appointed members of the Board undersection 3(6)(b) are to hold office as members in accordance with the terms andconditions of their appointment as members.

Official statistics: introductory
	Official statistics
		In this Part “official statistics” means—
			statistics produced by—
			the Board,
			a government department,
			the Scottish Administration,
			a Welsh ministerial authority,
			a Northern Ireland department, or
			any other person acting on behalf of the Crown, and
			such other statistics as may be specified by order by—
			a Minister of the Crown,
			the Scottish Ministers,
			the Welsh Ministers, or
			a Northern Ireland department.
		An order under subsection (1)(b) may in particular specify all, or adescription of, the statistics produced or to be produced by a particularperson or description of person.
		Before making an order under subsection (1)(b) an authority referred to inthat provision must consult the Board.
		The Board must, at least once every financial year, publish a list ofstatistics which are at the time of publication official statistics by virtueof subsection (1)(b).
		In this Part “Welsh ministerial authority” means any of the following—
			the Welsh Ministers;
			the First Minister for Wales;
			the Counsel General to the Welsh Assembly Government.
	Objective 
		In the exercise of its functions under sections 8 to 21 the Board is tohave the objective of promoting and safeguarding the production andpublication of official statistics that serve the public good.
		In subsection (1) the reference to serving the public good includes inparticular—
			informing the public about social and economic matters, and
			assisting in the development and evaluation of public policy.
		The Board is accordingly, in the exercise of its functions under sections 8to 21, to promote and safeguard—
			the quality of official statistics,
			good practice in relation to official statistics, and
			the comprehensiveness of official statistics.
		In this Part references to the quality of any official statistics includes—
			their impartiality, accuracy and relevance, and
			their coherence with other official statistics.
		In this Part references to good practice in relation to official statisticsincludes ensuring their accessibility.

General functions relating to official statistics
	Monitoring and reporting of official statistics
		The Board is to monitor the production and publication of officialstatistics.
		The Board may report any concerns it has about—
			the quality of any official statistics,
			good practice in relation to any official statistics, or
			the comprehensiveness of any official statistics,
				to the person responsible for those statistics.
		The Board may publish its findings or any report under this section.
	Definitions etc for official statistics
		The Board is to—
			develop and maintain definitions, methodologies, classifications andstandards for official statistics, and
			promote their use in relation to official statistics.
		The Board may in particular for the purposes of this section give guidanceand advice to persons responsible for official statistics.
		The Board may publish guidance and advice given under this section.

National Statistics
	Code of Practice for Statistics
		The Board is to prepare, adopt and publish a Code of Practice forStatistics.
		The Board may at any time revise the Code and, if it decides to do so, mustpublish the Code as revised.
		In preparing or revising the Code the Board must consult—
			the Scottish Ministers,
			the Welsh Ministers,
			the Department of Finance and Personnel for Northern Ireland, and
			such other persons as it thinks fit.
	Pre-release access
		The Code of Practice for Statistics under section 10 may not deal with anymatter relating to the granting of pre-release access to official statistics.
		The appropriate authority may for the purposes of the Code by order providefor rules and principles relating to the granting of pre-release access toofficial statistics.
		The Code shall apply in relation to any official statistics as if itincluded any rules and principles provided for in relation to those statisticsunder subsection (2).
		The rules and principles which may be provided for under subsection (2)include rules and principles as to—
			the circumstances in which, or descriptions of statistics in relation towhich, pre-release access may or may not be granted;
			the persons or descriptions of person to whom pre-release access may begranted;
			the period, or maximum period, during which pre-release access may be sogranted;
			the conditions subject to which pre-release access may be so granted.
		Those rules and principles may—
			make different provision for different cases, and
			allow for the exercise of discretion by persons responsible for officialstatistics.
		In this section “appropriate authority” means—
			the Minister for the Cabinet Office, except in a case falling withinparagraphs (b) to (d);
			the Scottish Ministers, in relation to official statistics that are whollyScottish devolved statistics;
			the Welsh Ministers, in relation to official statistics that are whollyWelsh devolved statistics;
			the Department of Finance and Personnel for Northern Ireland, in relationto official statistics that are wholly Northern Ireland devolved statistics.
		Before making an order under subsection (2) the appropriate authority mustconsult—
			the other persons referred to in subsection (6)(a) to (d), and
			the Board.
		In this section “pre-release access”, in relation to official statistics,means access to the statistics in their final form prior to publication.
	Assessment 
		At the request of the appropriate authority the Board must, in accordancewith this Part, assess and determine whether the Code of Practice forStatistics under section 10 has been complied with in relation to any officialstatistics.
		If under subsection (1) the Board determines that the Code has beencomplied with, it must designate the statistics as “National Statistics”; butotherwise it must decline so to designate them.
		A request under subsection (1) may not be withdrawn.
		The person responsible for any official statistics in relation to which anassessment is being made under subsection (1) must provide the Board with suchinformation about the statistics as it may reasonably require.
		The Board must publish the results of any assessment under subsection (1).
		The Board may in exercising its functions under subsection (1) take intoaccount information or advice received from any person.
		In subsection (1) the “appropriate authority” in relation to any officialstatistics is a Minister of the Crown, subject to the following—
			the National Statistician is the appropriate authority in relation tostatistics produced by the Board;
			the Scottish Ministers are the appropriate authority in relation toofficial statistics not produced by the Board which are Scottish devolvedstatistics;
			the Welsh Ministers are the appropriate authority in relation to officialstatistics not produced by the Board which are Welsh devolved statistics;
			any Northern Ireland department is the appropriate authority in relation toofficial statistics not produced by the Board which are Northern Irelanddevolved statistics.
		For the purposes of this Part, any official statistics designated asNational Statistics before the commencement of this section shall be regardedas having been so designated under this section.
	Duty to continue to comply with Code
		The person producing any official statistics which are designated undersection 12 as National Statistics must ensure that the Code of Practice forStatistics under section 10 continues to be complied with in relation to thestatistics.
		Failure to comply with subsection (1) in relation to any statistics meansthat the designation of the statistics as National Statistics may not beconfirmed under section 14 (but no action shall lie in relation to any suchfailure).
	Re-assessment 
		The Board must, in accordance with this Part, assess and determine whetherthe Code of Practice for Statistics under section 10 continues to be compliedwith in relation to statistics already designated as National Statistics undersection 12.
		If under subsection (1) the Board determines that the Code continues to becomplied with in relation to any statistics already designated as NationalStatistics under section 12, it must confirm their designation as NationalStatistics; but otherwise it must cancel their designation.
		The person responsible for any official statistics in respect of which anassessment is being made under subsection (1) must provide the Board with suchinformation about the statistics as it may reasonably require.
		The Board may in exercising its functions under subsection (1) take intoaccount information or advice received from any person.
		The Board must publish the results of any assessment under subsection (1).
		The designation of any statistics as National Statistics may not becancelled except pursuant to a determination under subsection (1).
	Programme of assessment
		The Board must prepare and publish a programme for the assessment and re-assessment of statistics under sections 12(1) and 14(1).
		The Board may at any time revise the programme and, if it decides to do so,must publish the programme as revised.
	Requests for assessment: supplementary
		Where in the case of any official statistics other than statistics producedby the Board—
			the appropriate authority has not under section 12(1) requested the Boardto assess and determine whether the Code of Practice for Statistics has beencomplied with, and
			the Board is of the view that it would be appropriate for it to do so,
				the Board must notify the appropriate authority accordingly.
		Where the appropriate authority is a Minister of the Crown, the Board mustlay a copy of its notification under subsection (1) before Parliament.
		A Minister of the Crown, on receiving notification under subsection (1),must provide the Board with—
			a statement that he intends to make a request under section 12(1) inrelation to the statistics, or
			a statement that he does not intend to make such a request,
			and must lay a copy of the statement before Parliament.
		A statement under subsection (3)(a) must include a timetable for making therequest.
		A statement under subsection (3)(b) must give reasons for not making therequest.
		Where the National Statistician determines not to make a request undersection 12(1) in relation to any official statistics produced by the Board, hemust—
			make a statement that he does not intend to make such a request, givingreasons, and
			lay a copy of the statement before Parliament.
		In this section “appropriate authority” has the same meaning as in section12(1).
	Principles and procedures
		The Board must prepare and publish a statement of—
			the principles to which it will have regard, and
			the procedures which it will adopt,
				in exercising its functions under sections 12(1) and 14(1).
		The Board may at any time revise the statement under subsection (1) and, ifit decides to do so, must publish the statement as revised.
		In preparing or revising the statement under subsection (1) the Board mustconsult—
			the Scottish Ministers,
			the Welsh Ministers,
			the Department of Finance and Personnel for Northern Ireland, and
			such other persons as it thinks fit.
	List of National Statistics
		The Board must, at least once every financial year, publish a list ofstatistics which are at the time of publication designated as NationalStatistics under this Part.
	Code: transitional
		In this section—
			“the interim period” means the period after the Board is established undersection 1 but before the Board has adopted and published a Code under section10(1), and
			“the existing Code” means the National Statistics Code of Practice existingat the time of the commencement of this section.
		During the interim period the Board is to maintain the existing Code.
		The Board may at any time during the interim period revise the existingCode and, if it decides to do so, must publish that Code as revised.
		The Board may not under subsection (3) make any revision relating to pre-release access to official statistics (within the meaning of section 11).
		Sections 11(2) to (7), 12 and 14 apply during the interim period inrelation to the existing Code as they apply in relation to the Code undersection 10.

Production of statistics
	Production of statistics
		The Board may itself produce and publish statistics relating to any matterrelating to the United Kingdom or any part of it.
		The Board may at any time publish information or give advice on statisticsproduced under subsection (1).
		The Board may not without the consent of the Scottish Ministers produce andpublish Scottish devolved statistics.
		The Board may not without the consent of a Welsh ministerial authorityproduce and publish Welsh devolved statistics.
		The Board may not without the consent of the appropriate Northern Irelanddepartment produce and publish Northern Ireland devolved statistics.
	Retail prices index
		The Board must under section 20—
			compile and maintain the retail prices index, and
			publish it every month.
		Before making any change to the coverage or the basic calculation of theretail prices index, the Board must consult the Bank of England as to whetherthe change constitutes a fundamental change in the index which would bematerially detrimental to the interests of the holders of relevant index-linked gilt-edged securities.
		If the Bank of England considers that the change constitutes a fundamentalchange in the index which would be materially detrimental to the interests ofthe holders of relevant index-linked gilt-edged securities, the Board may notmake the change without the consent of the Chancellor of the Exchequer.
		In this section —
			  * “index-linked gilt-edged securities” means securities issued under section 12 of the National Loans Act [1968 (c. 13)](/id/ukpga/1968/13?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") the amount of the payments under which is determined wholly or partly by reference to the retail prices index; 
			  * “relevant index-linked gilt-edged securities” means index-linked gilt-edged securities issued before the commencement of this section subject to a prospectus containing provision relating to early redemption in the event of a change to the retail prices index; 
			  * “retail prices index” means the United Kingdom General Index of Retail Prices.

Additional statistical functions
	Statistical services
		The Board may provide statistical services to any person in any placewithin or outside the United Kingdom.
		The services which may be provided under this section include inparticular—
			providing information, advice and technical assistance in relation tostatistics;
			providing quality assessment in relation to statistics;
			conducting statistical surveys and analysis;
			collecting, adapting and developing data.
	Statistical research
		The Board may promote and assist statistical research, in particular byproviding access (where it may lawfully do so) to data held by it.
	Delegated functions
		A Minister of the Crown may by order delegate to the Board any of hisfunctions relating to the production of statistics.
		A Welsh ministerial authority may by order delegate to the Board any of theauthority’s functions relating to the production of statistics.
		A Northern Ireland department may by order delegate to the Board any of itsfunctions relating to the production of statistics.
		An order under this section may include consequential or incidentalprovision (including provision amending any enactment).

Census etc
	Census etc
		The functions of the Registrar General for England and Wales under theenactments specified in subsection (2) are transferred to the Board.
		Those enactments are—
			the Census Act [1920 (c. 41)](/id/ukpga/1920/41?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation") (censuses);
			section 19 of the Registration Service Act [1953 (c.37)](/id/ukpga/1953/37?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (annualabstract of number of births, deaths and marriages);
			paragraph 5(a) and (c) of Schedule 1 to the Parliamentary ConstituenciesAct [1986 (c. 56)](/id/ukpga/1986/56?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")(function as assessor to Boundary Commission for England and BoundaryCommission for Wales).
		Schedule 1 (which makes consequential and supplementary provision relatingto the transfer of functions under subsection (1)) has effect.

Functions: supplementary
	Ancillary powers
		The Board may do anything which it thinks necessary or expedient for thepurpose of, or in connection with, the exercise of its functions.
		Anything required to be published by the Board may be published by it insuch manner as it thinks fit.
	Reports 
		As soon as possible after the end of each financial year the Board mustproduce a report on—
			what it has done during that year,
			what it has found during that year, and
			what it intends to do during the next financial year.
		The Board must lay a report under subsection (1) before—
			Parliament, 
			the Scottish Parliament,
			the National Assembly for Wales, and
			the Northern Ireland Assembly.
		The Board may at any time produce a report about any matter relating to theexercise of its functions.
		The Board must lay a report under subsection (3) before one or more of thefollowing—
			Parliament; 
			the Scottish Parliament;
			the National Assembly for Wales;
			the Northern Ireland Assembly.
		Where the Board lays a report under this section it must publish it as soonas possible thereafter.
	Efficiency etc
		The Board must exercise its functions efficiently and cost-effectively.
		The Board must seek to minimise the burdens (including financial burdens)it imposes on other persons.
	Directions 
		If the Minister for the Cabinet Office considers that there has been aserious failure by the Board—
			to comply with its objective, or
			to perform any of its functions,
				he may give the Board such directions as he considers appropriate to remedythe failure.
		If the Scottish Ministers consider that there has been a serious failure bythe Board—
			to comply with its objective, or
			to perform any of its functions so far as relating to Scottish devolvedstatistics,
			they may, with the consent of the Minister for the Cabinet Office, give theBoard such directions as they consider appropriate to remedy the failure.
		If the Welsh Ministers consider that there has been a serious failure bythe Board—
			to comply with its objective, or
			to perform any of its functions so far as relating to Welsh devolvedstatistics,
			they may, with the consent of the Minister for the Cabinet Office, give theBoard such directions as they consider appropriate to remedy the failure.
		If the Department of Finance and Personnel for Northern Ireland considersthat there has been a serious failure by the Board—
			to comply with its objective, or
			to perform any of its functions so far as relating to Northern Irelanddevolved statistics,
			it may, with the consent of the Minister for the Cabinet Office, give theBoard such directions as it considers appropriate to remedy the failure.
		The Minister for the Cabinet Office may give the Board such directions ashe considers appropriate for the purpose of implementing any Communityobligation.
		A direction under this section must be in writing.
		A direction under this section must be published by the authority whichgave it in such manner as that authority considers appropriate for the purposeof bringing it to the attention of persons likely to be affected by it.
		Where the Minister for the Cabinet Office gives a direction under thissection—
			he must lay a copy before Parliament, and
			he must notify the Scottish Ministers, the Welsh Ministers and theDepartment of Finance and Personnel for Northern Ireland of the direction, whomust lay a copy before the Scottish Parliament, the National Assembly forWales and the Northern Ireland Assembly respectively.
		Where the Scottish Ministers give a direction under this section—
			they must lay a copy before the Scottish Parliament, and
			the Minister for the Cabinet Office must lay a copy before Parliament.
		Where the Welsh Ministers give a direction under this section—
			they must lay a copy before the National Assembly for Wales, and
			the Minister for the Cabinet Office must lay a copy before Parliament.
		Where the Department of Finance and Personnel for Northern Ireland gives adirection under this section—
			it must lay a copy before the Northern Ireland Assembly, and
			the Minister for the Cabinet Office must lay a copy before Parliament.
		If the Board fails to comply with any direction given to it under thissection, the authority which gave the direction may give effect to it, and forthat purpose may exercise any function of the Board.
		But the Scottish Ministers, the Welsh Ministers and the Department ofFinance and Personnel for Northern Ireland may only give effect to a directionunder subsection (12) with the consent of the Minister for the Cabinet Office.

Organisation and administration
	National Statistician: advisory functions
		The National Statistician is to be the Board’s principal adviser on—
			the quality of official statistics,
			good practice in relation to official statistics, and
			the comprehensiveness of official statistics.
		The Board must have regard to the advice of the National Statistician onthose matters.
		If the Board rejects the advice of the National Statistician—
			in relation to the development and maintenance of definitions,methodologies, classifications and standards for official statistics, or
			as to the application to any statistics produced by the Board of anydefinition, methodology, classification or standard promoted by the Boardunder section 9,
				the Board must publish a statement of its reasons for doing so.
		Where the Board publishes a statement under subsection (3), it must as soonas possible thereafter lay a copy before Parliament.
	National Statistician: executive functions
		The National Statistician is also to be the chief executive of the Board.
		The National Statistician may, subject as follows, exercise any of thefunctions of the Board (including functions of establishing committees undersection 35 and delegating functions to such committees).
		The National Statistician may not exercise the functions of—
			determining under section 10 whether to adopt a code as the Code ofPractice for Statistics or to revise the Code, or
			determining under section 12(1) or 14(1) whether any official statisticscomply with the Code.
		The Board may direct the National Statistician—
			not to exercise a particular function, or
			as to how he should exercise a particular function.
		In the event of a vacancy in the office of National Statistician, hisfunctions under this section and section 32 may be exercised by such one ofthe other executive members of the Board as the Board may direct.
	Executive office
		The National Statistician must establish an executive office of the Boardto assist him in his exercise of—
			the function of the Board under section 9(1)(a) (development andmaintenance of definitions, methodologies, classifications and standards forofficial statistics),
			the function of the Board under section 20 (production of statistics),
			the function of the Board under section 21 (retail prices index),
			the function of the Board under section 22 (statistical services), and
			any other function of the Board which he may exercise under section 31(2).
		The executive office is, subject to this Act, to consist of—
			the National Statistician (who is to be its head),
			the other executive members of the Board, and
			such other employees of the Board as the National Statistician may assignto it.
		For the purposes of subsection (1) the National Statistician may delegateany function of the Board referred to in that subsection to any other memberof the executive office.
		The delegation of a function by the National Statistician under subsection(3) does not prevent him from exercising the function himself.
	Head of Assessment
		The Head of Assessment is to be the Board’s principal adviser on theexercise of its functions under sections 12(1) and 14(1).
		The Board must have regard to the advice of the Head of Assessment in theexercise of those functions.
		The Head of Assessment—
			if an executive member of the Board, may not exercise functions of theNational Statistician under section 31(5),
			may not be a member of the executive office of the Board under section32(2)(b) or (c), and
			may not in any other way take part in the production of statistics by theBoard.
	Separation of functions
		The National Statistician may not take part in any assessment ordetermination of the Board under section 12(1) or 14(1) in relation tostatistics produced by the Board.
		The following may not take part in any assessment or determination of theBoard under section 12(1) or 14(1)—
			an executive member of the Board, not being the National Statistician orHead of Assessment;
			a person assigned to the executive office of the Board under section32(2)(c).
		The Board must seek to secure that, so far as practicable, employees whotake part in the production of statistics should not be engaged in advisingthe Board on the exercise of its functions under sections 12(1) and 14(1) inrelation to those statistics.
	Committees 
		The Board may establish committees for the purpose of—
			exercising functions of the Board, or
			giving advice to the Board.
		A committee of the Board established under subsection (1)(b) may includepersons who are neither members nor employees of the Board.
		A committee established under this section may establish one or more sub-committees.
	Delegation 
		Subject as follows, the Board may delegate any of its functions (generallyor specifically) to—
			a member of the Board,
			an employee of the Board not assigned to the executive office of the Board,or
			a committee established under section 35(1)(a).
		The Board may not under this section delegate the functions of—
			determining under section 10 whether to adopt or revise the Code ofPractice for Statistics, or
			determining under section 12(1) or 14(1) whether any official statisticscomply with the Code.
		Any committee of the Board established under section 35(1)(a) may delegateany function exercisable by it to any of its sub-committees.
		The delegation of a function by the Board or a committee of the Board underthis section does not prevent the Board or committee from exercising thefunction.
	Proceedings: supplementary
		Subject to this Part, the Board may regulate—
			its own proceedings (including quorum);
			the proceedings (including quorum) of any of its committees.
		A committee of the Board may regulate the proceedings (including quorum) ofany of its sub-committees.
		The validity of any proceedings of the Board, or of any of its committeesor sub-committees, is not affected by—
			a vacancy, or
			a defective appointment.

Use and disclosure of information by the Board
	Use of information by the Board
		Any information obtained by the Board in relation to the exercise of any ofits functions may be used by it in relation to the exercise of any of itsother functions.
		Subsection (1) does not apply to information obtained by the Board inrelation to the exercise of its functions under sections 12(1) and 14(1).
		Subsection (1) does not apply to information obtained by the Board inrelation to the exercise of its functions under section 22, unless the personfrom whom the Board receives the information consents to its use as specifiedin that subsection.
		Subsection (1) is subject to any enactment which restricts or prohibits theuse or disclosure of information.
	Confidentiality of personal information
		Subject to this section, personal information held by the Board in relationto the exercise of any of its functions must not be disclosed by—
			any member or employee of the Board,
			a member of any committee of the Board, or
			any other person who has received it directly or indirectly from the Board.
		In this Part “personal information” means information which relates to andidentifies a particular person (including a body corporate); but it does notinclude information about the internal administrative arrangements of theBoard (whether relating to its members, employees or other persons).
		For the purposes of subsection (2) information identifies a particularperson if the identity of that person—
			is specified in the information,
			can be deduced from the information, or
			can be deduced from the information taken together with any other publishedinformation.
		Subsection (1) does not apply to a disclosure which—
			is required or permitted by any enactment,
			is required by a Community obligation,
			is necessary for the purpose of enabling or assisting the Board to exerciseany of its functions,
			has already lawfully been made available to the public,
			is made in pursuance of an order of a court,
			is made for the purposes of a criminal investigation or criminalproceedings (whether or not in the United Kingdom),
			is made, in the interests of national security, to an Intelligence Service,
			is made with the consent of the person to whom it relates, or
			is made to an approved researcher.
		For the purposes of subsection (4)(i), “approved researcher” means anindividual to whom the Board has granted access, for the purposes ofstatistical research, to personal information held by it.
		The Board is from time to time to publish criteria by reference to which itwill determine whether to grant access as specified in subsection (5).
		Those criteria must require the Board to consider—
			whether the individual is a fit and proper person, and
			the purpose for which access is requested.

		A person who contravenes subsection (1) is guilty of an offence and liable—

Power to authorise disclosure to the Board
	Subject to this section, the Minister for the Cabinet Office may makeregulations for the purpose of authorising a public authority to discloseinformation to the Board where—
		the disclosure would otherwise be prohibited by a rule of law or an Actpassed before this Act, or
		the authority would not otherwise have power to make the disclosure.
	Regulations under subsection (1) may only authorise disclosure to enablethe Board to carry out one or more of its functions, other than its functionunder section 22 (statistical services).
	The Board may only use information received under regulations undersubsection (1) for the purposes for which disclosure is authorised undersubsection (2).
	In the application of section 39 to personal information which has beendisclosed to the Board under regulations under subsection (1), paragraphs (c)and (i) of subsection (4) of that section do not apply (subject to anyprovision made under subsection (7)(b) below).
	Regulations under subsection (1) may not authorise disclosure by—
		a Scottish public authority, so far as exercising functions which relate tomatters which are not reserved matters, or
		a Northern Ireland public authority.

		amend or modify any enactment;
		contain consequential and supplementary provision.
	The consequential and supplementary provision referred to in subsection(6)(b) includes in particular provision—
		prohibiting or restricting further disclosure by the Board of informationdisclosed under the regulations;

Consequential
	Cessation of Office for National Statistics etc
		The following shall cease to function on the commencement of this section—
			the Office for National Statistics;
			the Statistics Commission.
	Transfers etc from ONS to the Board
		Subject to subsection (6), on commencement of this section the property,rights and liabilities of the Office for National Statistics and of theNational Statistician shall by virtue of this section vest in the Board.
		Subsection (1) shall operate in relation to property, rights andliabilities—
			whether or not they would otherwise be capable of being transferred,
			without any instrument or other formality being required, and
			irrespective of any requirement for consent that would otherwise apply.
		Anything done by, on behalf of or in relation to the Office for NationalStatistics or the National Statistician which has effect immediately beforethe commencement of this section shall continue to have effect as if done by,on behalf of or in relation to the Board.
		Anything (including legal proceedings) which immediately beforecommencement of this section is in the process of being done by, on behalf ofor in relation to the Office for National Statistics or the NationalStatistician may be continued by, on behalf of or in relation to the Board.
		So far as is necessary or appropriate in consequence of the precedingprovisions of this section, on and after commencement of this section areference to the Office for National Statistics or the National Statisticianin an agreement (whether written or not), instrument or other document shallbe treated as a reference to the Board.
		The Minister for the Cabinet Office may make a scheme or schemesidentifying property, rights and liabilities of the Office for NationalStatistics or the National Statistician (or both) which shall not vest in theBoard on commencement of this section but shall vest in the Registrar Generalfor England and Wales or a Minister of the Crown (including the Minister forthe Cabinet Office).
		A scheme under subsection (6) shall have effect—
			in so far as it excludes anything from the operation of subsection (1), oncommencement of this section, and
			in so far as it vests anything in the Registrar General or Minister of theCrown, on such date as may be specified in the scheme.
		A scheme under subsection (6) may operate in relation to property, rightsand liabilities as specified in subsection (2)(a), (b) and (c).
		A scheme under subsection (6) may include consequential and incidentalprovision and may in particular—
			make provision for the continuing effect of things done by the Office forNational Statistics or the National Statistician before commencement of thissection;
			make provision for the continuation of things (including legal proceedings)in the process of being done by, on behalf of or in relation to the Office forNational Statistics or the National Statistician immediately beforecommencement of this section;
			make provision for references to the Office for National Statistics or theNational Statistician in an agreement (whether written or not), instrument orother document to be treated as references to the Registrar General or aMinister of the Crown;
			make provision for shared ownership, use or access.
		Where a scheme has been made under subsection (6), the Board and theRegistrar General or the Minister of the Crown may agree in writing to modifythe scheme (and any such modification shall have effect as from the date theoriginal scheme came into effect).
		In this section “the National Statistician” means the NationalStatistician who holds office immediately before the commencement of section1.
	Transfers etc from Registrar General to the Board
		On commencement of this section the property, rights and liabilities of theRegistrar General for England and Wales held or incurred in relation to thefunctions transferred under section 25 (the “transferred functions”) shall byvirtue of this section vest in the Board.
		Subsection (1) shall operate in relation to property, rights andliabilities—
			whether or not they would otherwise be capable of being transferred,
			without any instrument or other formality being required, and
			irrespective of any requirement for consent that would otherwise apply.
		Anything done by, on behalf of or in relation to the Registrar General inrespect of the transferred functions which has effect immediately beforecommencement of this section shall continue to have effect as if done by, onbehalf of or in relation to the Board.
		Anything (including legal proceedings) which immediately beforecommencement of this section is in the process of being done by, on behalf ofor in relation to the Registrar General in respect of, or connected with, thetransferred functions, may be continued by, on behalf of or in relation to theBoard.
		So far as is necessary or appropriate in consequence of the precedingprovisions of this section, on and after commencement of this section areference to the Registrar General in an agreement (whether written or not),instrument or other document shall be treated as a reference to the Board.
	Transfers etc from Ministers of the Crown to the Board
		The Minister for the Cabinet Office may make a scheme or schemestransferring property, rights and liabilities from a Minister of the Crown tothe Board and such transfer shall have effect in accordance with the terms ofthe scheme.

General
	Orders and regulations
		Any power to make an order or regulations under this Part is exercisable—
			in the case of an order or regulations made by the Minister for the CabinetOffice or other Minister of the Crown, the Scottish Ministers or a Welshministerial authority, by statutory instrument, and
			in the case of an order or regulations made by a Northern Irelanddepartment, by statutory rule for the purposes of the Statutory Rules(Northern Ireland) Order 1979 ([SI 1979/1573 (NI12)](/id/nisi/1979/1573?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")).
		A Minister of the Crown may not make an order under section 6(1)(b) unlessa draft of the statutory instrument containing the order has been laid before,and approved by resolution of, each House of Parliament.
		A statutory instrument containing an order made by a Minister of the Crownunder section 24 that includes consequential or incidental provision amendingany relevant legislation is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolutionof either House of Parliament.
		A statutory instrument containing an order made by the Minister for theCabinet Office under section 47(11), 50(7) or 51(11) is subject to annulmentin pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
		The Minister for the Cabinet Office may not make—
			an order under section 11, or
			regulations under section 47, 50 or 51,
				unless a draft of the statutory instrument containing the order or regulationshas been laid before, and approved by resolution of, each House of Parliament.
		The Scottish Ministers may not make—
			an order under section 6(1)(b) or 11, or
			regulations under section 48 or 52,
			unless a draft of the instrument containing the order or regulations has beenlaid before, and approved by resolution of, the Scottish Parliament.
		The Welsh Ministers may not make an order under section 6(1)(b) or 11unless a draft of the instrument containing the order has been laid before,and approved by resolution of, the National Assembly for Wales.
		A statutory instrument containing an order made by a Welsh ministerialauthority under section 24 that includes consequential or incidental provisionamending any relevant legislation is subject to annulment in pursuance of aresolution of the National Assembly for Wales.
		A statutory rule containing—
			an order made by a Northern Ireland department under section 6(1)(b),
			an order made by the Department of Finance and Personnel for NorthernIreland under section 11, or
			regulations made by a Northern Ireland department under section 49 or 53,
			is subject to affirmative resolution, within the meaning of section 41(4) ofthe Interpretation Act (Northern Ireland) 1954 ([1954 c. 33(NI)](/id/apni/1954/33?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")).
		A statutory rule containing an order made by a Northern Ireland departmentunder section 24 that includes consequential or incidental provision amendingany relevant legislation is subject to negative resolution, within the meaningof section 41(6) of the Interpretation Act (Northern Ireland) 1954.
		In this section, “relevant legislation” means—
			an Act of Parliament;
			an Act of the Scottish Parliament;
			Northern Ireland legislation;
			a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales.
	Devolved statistics
		In this Part “Scottish devolved statistics” means—
			statistics which relate to matters in Scotland which are not reservedmatters, unless the statistics are produced by a person acting on behalf ofthe Crown or a public authority in the exercise of functions in relation to areserved matter,
			statistics which relate to matters in Scotland which are reserved matters,where the statistics are produced by a person acting on behalf of the Crown ora public authority in the exercise of functions in relation to a matter whichis not a reserved matter, and
			statistics produced by the Scottish Ministers in the exercise of a functionwhich is exercisable by them pursuant to an Order made under section 63(1)(a)of the Scotland Act [1998 (c. 46)](/id/ukpga/1998/46?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation").
		But statistics are not Scottish devolved statistics by virtue of subsection(1)(a) or (b) if they are produced by—
			an authority which is a cross-border public authority within the meaning ofthe Scotland Act 1998, or
			an authority which is treated as a cross-border public authority for thepurposes of sections 23(2)(b) and 70(6) of that Act,
				and do not relate wholly to Scotland.
		In this Part “Welsh devolved statistics” means statistics which relatewholly or mainly to the exercise of functions by—
			a Welsh ministerial authority, or
			any other public authority whose functions are exercisable only in or asregards Wales,
			unless the statistics are produced by a person acting on behalf of the Crownor a public authority in the exercise of functions in relation to a matterwhich does not so relate.
		In this Part “Northern Ireland devolved statistics” means—
			statistics which relate to matters in Northern Ireland which aretransferred matters, unless the statistics are produced by a person acting onbehalf of the Crown or a public authority in the exercise of functions inrelation to a matter which is not a transferred matter, and
			statistics which relate to matters in Northern Ireland which are nottransferred matters, where the statistics are produced by a person acting onbehalf of the Crown or a public authority in the exercise of functions inrelation to matter which is a transferred matter.
	General interpretation
		In this Part—
		  * “enactment” includes— 
			an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, an Act of theScottish Parliament;
			an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, Northern Irelandlegislation;
				  * “Intelligence Service” means— 
			the Security Service,
			the Secret Intelligence Service, or
			GCHQ (within the meaning of the Intelligence Services Act [1994 (c.13)](/id/ukpga/1994/13?view=plain "Go to item of legislation"));
				  * “Minister of the Crown” has the same meaning as in the Ministers of the Crown Act [1975 (c. 26)](/id/ukpga/1975/26?view=plain "Go to item of legislation"); 
				  * “Northern Ireland devolved statistics” has the meaning given by section 66(4); 
				  * “Northern Ireland public authority” means a public authority whose functions— 
			are exercisable only or mainly in or as regards Northern Ireland, and
			relate only or mainly to transferred matters;
				  * “official statistics” has the meaning given by section 6(1); 
				  * “person responsible”, in relation to any official statistics, means— 
			in the case of official statistics produced by the Board, the NationalStatistician,
			in the case of official statistics produced by a government department, theMinister in charge of the department, and
			in any other case, the person producing the statistics;
				  * “personal information” has the meaning given by section 39(2); 
				  * “public authority” (except in section 40(1)) means— 
			a person or body exercising functions of a public nature in the UnitedKingdom,
			a person or body entirely or substantially funded from public money,
			an office-holder appointed by a person or body falling within paragraph (a),or
			a body more than half of whose governing body or members are appointed by aperson or body falling within paragraph (a);
				  * “reserved matters” has the same meaning as in the Scotland Act [1998 (c. 46)](/id/ukpga/1998/46?view=plain "Go to item of legislation"); 
				  * “rights and liabilities” includes rights and liabilities relating to employment; 
				  * “Scottish devolved statistics” has the meaning given by section 66(1) and (2); 
				  * “Scottish public authority” (except in section 40(3)) has the same meaning as in the Scotland Act 1998; 
				  * “transferred matters” has the same meaning as in the Northern Ireland Act [1998 (c. 47)](/id/ukpga/1998/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation"); 
				  * “Welsh devolved statistics” has the meaning given by section 66(3); 
				  * “Welsh ministerial authority” has the meaning given by section 6(5).

	Establishment of Registrar General as corporation sole
		Section 1 of the Registration Service Act [1953 (c.37)](/id/ukpga/1953/37?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") is amended asfollows—
			renumber the existing provision as subsection (1);
			after that subsection insert—
		The Registrar General is a corporation sole by the name of the RegistrarGeneral for England and Wales.
		The Registrar General may do anything (including acquire or dispose of anyproperty or rights) which is calculated to facilitate, or is conducive orincidental to, the discharge of any of his functions.
		The Registrar General discharges his functions on behalf of the Crown.
		Service as Registrar General is not service in the civil service of theCrown; but the Registrar General is a Crown servant for the purposes of theOfficial Secrets Act 1989.”
		Subject to section 57, the property, rights and liabilities of theRegistrar General on the commencement of this section shall at that timebecome the property, rights and liabilities of the Registrar General as acorporation sole.
	Employment status of officials
		On commencement of this section, every person who immediately beforecommencement of this section holds a relevant office becomes an employee ofthe relevant local authority.
		The relevant offices are—
			superintendent registrar of births, deaths and marriages appointed undersection 6 of the Registration Service Act 1953;
			registrar of births and deaths appointed under that section;
			deputy superintendent registrar of births, deaths and marriages appointedunder section 8 of that Act;
			deputy registrar of births and deaths appointed under that section.
		The terms and conditions of appointment of the holder of a relevant officehave effect from commencement of this section (subject to any necessarymodifications) as the terms and conditions of his employment with the relevantlocal authority.
		On commencement of this section any liabilities incurred by the holder of arelevant office in connection with the exercise of his functions aretransferred to the relevant local authority.
		Any period which ends immediately before commencement of this sectionduring which a person was continuously—
			the holder of a relevant office (whether in respect of the same ordifferent relevant offices), or
			the holder of a relevant office (whether in respect of the same ordifferent relevant offices) or an employee of a local authority,
				must be treated as a period of continuous employment with the relevant localauthority.
		If, immediately before commencement of this section, the holder of arelevant office was a member of a pension scheme established in pursuance ofregulations under sections 7 and 12 of the Superannuation Act [1972 (c.11)](/id/ukpga/1972/11?view=plain "Go to item of legislation"), he continuesto be a member of the scheme by virtue of his becoming an employee of therelevant local authority.
		For the purposes of this section, the “relevant local authority” is—
			in relation to the holder of a relevant office falling within subsection(2)(a) or (b), the local authority by which he was appointed;
			in relation to the holder of a relevant office falling within subsection(2)(c) or (d), the local authority which appointed the superintendentregistrar of births, deaths and marriages or registrar of births and deaths bywhom he was appointed.
		For the purposes of this section, each of the following is a localauthority—
			a county council in England;
			a district council in England for an area without a county council;
			a London borough council;
			the Common Council of the City of London;
			the Council of the Isles of Scilly;
			a county or county borough council in Wales.

Part 3General
	Repeals

	Commencement 
		The preceding provisions of this Act shall come into such force inaccordance with provision made by order made by statutory instrument by theMinister for the Cabinet Office.
		An order under this section may—
			make different provision for different purposes;
			include supplementary, consequential and transitional provision andsavings.
	Extent 
		This Act extends to England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland,subject as follows.
		Section 62 does not extend to Scotland.
		Part 2 does not extend to Scotland or Northern Ireland (subject tosubsection (4)).
		An amendment or repeal effected by this Act has the same extent as theenactment to which it relates.
	Short title
